comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: How about looking East from Harrington Street towards Harcourt Road. The Church could be St Matthias..... ...but the tram points on OSI are not in the photo. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,715536,732773,7,9 The Harcourt Pharmacy is now Harcourt Health

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The building on the corner is called the Harcourt Pharmacy. There is a Post Office on the right, as on the OSI map. So, I think blackpoolbeach has it! Charlotte Street to the right, Charlemont Street to the left. The Church in the distance is St. Kevin's on the South Circular, and the Harcourt Pharmacy is a Bagel Factory now. Streetview, much changed. Wait, did you say East? I think this is looking West along Harcourt Road towards the South Circular.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] DannyM8 had it right first, Kellys Corner.
The women are all in black. Queen Victoria's mourning?

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Kellys Corner Have a look at this it says Kellys Corner and it is looking back to where our photographer took the photo.

comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: Detail in the picture is incredible, could look at it all day! I agree with everyone, it's taken up at Harcourt Road, wonder did they get the locations mixed up when considering the association the two streets had with the adjacent railway termini.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: x Marks the spot so looking toward Kellys Corner but not Kellys corner This intersection has disappeared with the development of Charlotte Street

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
GIven the lack of corners in the tramlines (as marked on the map) I think it's where Harcourt road crosses Charlotte St. rather than Camden St.

Edit: Again with the lemur slowness.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley]  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] 
I stand corrected.
Strange coincidence with Harcourt Pharmacy and Harcourt Health, but they are on different corners on different streets.
On the right, the northern part of Charlotte Street has been built over.
Time for another lie down in a dark room.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Poster at left for "The Geraldos", could this be Madaline & Rene Geraldo, trapeze artists? If so, it's well after 1900. Or maybe their act was in the family...

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Posters at left for the Tivoli: from wikipedia: It became known as the Tivloi in 1901. It was a modest sized music hall with seating for 1252 patrons. The Tivoli closed in 1928 nli archive picture!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Throughout 112 years of cinematic history Dublin has featured film venues ranging from the upmarket (such as the METROPOLE on O'Connell Street, 1922-72) to the ramshackle (e.g. PICTUREDROME, Harcourt Road, c. 1912-22) From The History of Dublin Cinemas, apparently. The OSI 25" map marks it as a Hall, surveyed in 1907.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think I see Mr. and Mrs. Majestic in the Tivoli poster.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Does anyone know when Watkins brewery ceased trading under it's own name? I have it merging with North Anne Street brewery in 1904, but I don't know which name they resultant organisation used.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: According to blackpoolbeach on the recent TCD photo, the round electric streetlamp pictured was defunct by 1910. img.photobucket.com/albums/v219/Dublin1/1904.jpg Edit: Actually, that's a misinterpretation by me. The previous design disappeared in this timeframe, and was replaced by the design we see here. It doesn't seem to say when they were removed.

comment.author: 33461231@N00
comment._content: Picturedome in 1900?

comment.author: 34574252@N02
comment._content: The sign noted on the photograph [right hand side near the cross roads] 'Duval's Dye Works' - they are in the 1913 Dublin telephone directory as "Duval et Cie [Dye Works] 2, Pembroke Rd, Ballsbridgephone Ballsbridge 265"

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] It's hard to equate that empty junction with the wires all above the road with the junction we all know and hate today!  How things have changed over the years?  Great work while I was away Carol, great to be back and see the crowds coming out of the Garda Club on Harrington Street again!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: I worked in this area in the mid to late 1980's and there was a pub on the same site (right of the tram) up to near the end of the decade, before it was demolished to make way for the redevelopment. The pub was named Gleesons and run by the Gleeson family who from memory had a connection with the Gleesons of Borrisoleigh, County Tipperary.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
There is a lot of information on the redevelopment of the area associated with this picture.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/6933643308/in/photostream]

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] yep. (incidentally, as there's no aricraft to be seen, the flak burst must be time-fused rather than proximity-fused, making it '30s at the latest. Or a thumbprint).

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I worry about our friend teufelbeutel!  He saw anti aircraft guns in a 1900's shot (not a good choice of word?) of Moville.  I had always wondered what scared away the German and Allied armies during the emergency and obviously it was the shafts of the ass carts and pony traps that the devious Irish turned up to fool the spy planes.  Thumbprints on old photos were just as effective it seems;-)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
Just looking at some of the posters on the left of the shot and I'm surprised that nobody commented on Kennedy's bread.  Do you remember the jingle?  Lets go now-
K for Kennedy
E for energy
N for nice and
   nourishing.......
The NC laundry is one I never heard of before, I always marvelled at the famous "Bell and Swastika" laundry over in Ballsbridge.  Lasted right into the 70's!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
King Edward VII died in May 1910. I am guessing that the women are all in black mourning.
The new King George V's coronation took place at Westminster Abbey on 22 June 1911,
How about 1910/1911 for this photo?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I'm not sure that the ladies being in black is at all unusual. It seems quite common in B&W pictures of the time.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: I'm inclined to agree with [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] - black clothing not unusual. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] And if it's mourning, it could just as easily be for their family members...
